metadata.titleEn: Global daily 0.05 ° spatiotemporal continuous land surface temperature dataset (2002-2022)
metadata.description:
Land surface temperature (LST) is a key parameter in the study of surface energy balance. It is widely used in the fields of meteorology, climate, hydrology, agriculture and ecology. As an important means to obtain global and regional scale LST information, satellite (thermal infrared) remote sensing is vulnerable to the influence of cloud cover and other atmospheric conditions, resulting in temporal and spatial discontinuity of LST remote sensing products, which greatly limits the application of LST remote sensing products in related research fields.
The preparation of this data set is based on the empirical orthogonal function interpolation method, using Terra / Aqua MODIS surface temperature products to reconstruct the lst under ideal clear sky conditions, and then using the cumulative distribution function matching method to fuse era5 land reanalysis data to obtain the lst under all-weather conditions. This method makes full use of the spatio-temporal information of the original MODIS remote sensing products and the cloud impact information in the reanalysis data, alleviates the impact of cloud cover on LST estimation, and finally reconstructs the high-quality global 0.05 ° spatio-temporal continuous ideal clear sky and all-weather LST data set.
This data set not only realizes the seamless coverage of space-time, but also has good verification accuracy. The reconstructed ideal clear sky LST data in the experimental areas of 17 land cover types in the world, the average correlation coefficient (R) is 0.971, the bias (bias) is -0.001 K to 0.049 K, and the root mean square error (RMSE) is 1.436 K to 2.688 K. The verification results of the reconstructed all-weather LST data and the measured data of ground stations: the average R is 0.895, the bias is 0.025 K to 2.599 K, and the RMSE is 4.503 K to 7.299 K.
The time resolution of this data set is 4 times a day, the spatial resolution is 0.05 °, the time span is 2002-2022, and the spatial range covers the world.
metadata.instructions:
File naming:
(1) Global 0.05° spatiotemporal continuous ideal clear-sky land surface temperature dataset, file naming:
<MOD11C1(MYD11C1)_YYYYDDD_Clear-sky>.h5, MOD11C1(MYD11C1) represents the MODIS LST product of Terra (Aqua) sun-synchronous satellite, <YYYY> is the year, <DDD> represents the day of year, and <Clear-sky> represents it is ideal clear-sky MODIS LST product.
(2) Global 0.05° spatiotemporal continuous all-weather land surface temperature dataset, file naming:
<MOD11C1(MYD11C1)_YYYYDDD_All-weather>.h5, MOD11C1(MYD11C1) represents the MODIS LST product of Terra (Aqua) sun-synchronous satellite, <YYYY> is the year, <DDD> represents the day of year, and < All-weather > represents it is all-weather MODIS LST product.
How to use:
The data can be read in various programming languages such as Matlab, Python, IDL, etc., and can also be visualized in Panoply. When reading data from a scientific data set, it needs to be multiplied by its corresponding scale factor. For details, please refer to the description documentation.

background: Land surface temperature (LST) plays a critical role in land surface processes. However, as one of the effective means for obtaining global LST observations, remote sensing observations are inherently affected by cloud cover, resulting in varying degrees of missing data in satellite-derived LST products.
challenges: However, these reanalysis datasets are usually output with coarse resolutions, and the effects of surface properties on LSTs are only roughly considered in these numerical models, which are unable to meet the requirements of many applications, which demand LSTs with finer resolution. However, this category of algorithms works only under clear-sky conditions; thus, when affected by clouds or other atmospheric disturbances, an MODIS LST product may possess large proportions of missing data, which greatly limits the application of MODIS LST products. However, the abovementioned methods can only reconstruct the missing LST values under ideal, clear-sky conditions but cannot construct real LSTs under cloudy sky conditions. However, some of these methods need to calculate regional parameters from ground-based measurements, and some are not effective when larger areas of data are missing, so they are difficult to apply to LST reconstruction at large scales from global perspectives.
methods: In the first step is to use the DINEOF reconstruction process to obtain the ideal clear-sky LSTs for cloud-contaminated areas. In the second step, the ideal clear-sky LSTs are corrected to the real LSTs by a cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching-based method with LSTs from the ERA5-Land climate reanalysis data. We use the level-3 daily global LST products (MOD11C1/MYD11C1, Collection 6) provided by two polar-orbiting sun-synchronous satellites, Terra and Aqua (10:30 AM/PM and 1:30 AM/PM local solar time, respectively), from the NASA Earth Observing System, which provide temperature and emissivity values at 0.05° latitude/longitude climate model grids (CMGs). In this work, we also include the climate reanalysis data from ERA5-Land’s skin temperature data (hereinafter referred to as ERA5-Land LST data) based on the HTESSEL model.
dataset: We use the level-3 daily global LST products (MOD11C1/MYD11C1, Collection 6) provided by two polar-orbiting sun-synchronous satellites, Terra and Aqua (10:30 AM/PM and 1:30 AM/PM local solar time, respectively), from the NASA Earth Observing System, which provide temperature and emissivity values at 0.05° latitude/longitude climate model grids (CMGs). In this work, we also include the climate reanalysis data from ERA5-Land’s skin temperature data (hereinafter referred to as ERA5-Land LST data) based on the HTESSEL model.
findings: Overall, the DINEOF method showed good performance, with an average R of 0.971, a minimum Bias of −0.001 K, a maximum Bias of 0.049 K, and an RMSE between 1.436 K and 2.688 K. From the above statistical metrics, it is shown that the DINEOF method generally effectively reconstructs missing LST information under all land cover types. Overall, the combination of the DINEOF reconstruction method and the CDF matching-based correction method is an effective approach for MODIS LST reconstruction.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a method used to reconstruct land surface temperature data in areas affected by cloud cover?
Example.Answer: An example of a method used to reconstruct land surface temperature data in cloud-contaminated areas is the DINEOF reconstruction process. This method first obtains ideal clear-sky LSTs and then corrects them to real LSTs using a cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching-based method with LSTs from the ERA5-Land climate reanalysis data.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting land surface temperature data through satellite remote sensing?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in collecting land surface temperature data through satellite remote sensing is the influence of cloud cover, which leads to missing data in satellite-derived LST products. This issue significantly limits the application of these products in various research domains.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that integrates multiple sources to provide land surface temperature information on a global scale?

This integration helps mitigate the impact of cloud cover on LST estimates.

Definition.Question: What is the DINEOF reconstruction process in the context of land surface temperature data collection?
Definition.Answer: The DINEOF reconstruction process is a method used to obtain ideal clear-sky land surface temperatures (LSTs) for areas affected by cloud contamination. It is the first step in reconstructing missing LST information in satellite-derived products.

Definition.Question: What are cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching-based methods in the context of LST data reconstruction?
Definition.Answer: Cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching-based methods are techniques used to correct ideal clear-sky LSTs to real LSTs by matching them with LSTs from climate reanalysis data, such as the ERA5-Land skin temperature data, to account for atmospheric disturbances.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using MOD11C1/MYD11C1 level-3 daily global LST products in LST data collection?
Definition.Answer: The MOD11C1/MYD11C1 level-3 daily global LST products are significant in LST data collection as they provide temperature and emissivity values at 0.05° latitude/longitude climate model grids, offering high spatial resolution data from Terra and Aqua satellites, crucial for reconstructing high-quality global LST data.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the challenges associated with reconstructing LST values under ideal clear-sky conditions compared to real cloudy sky conditions?
Comparison.Answer: Reconstructing LST values under ideal clear-sky conditions primarily deals with filling in data gaps caused by cloud cover. In contrast, reconstructing real LSTs under cloudy conditions involves correcting these values to account for atmospheric disturbances, which is more complex and requires additional correction methods like CDF matching.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological advancements are necessary to enhance the spatial resolution of LST datasets used in land surface processes?
Interpretation.Answer: To enhance the spatial resolution of LST datasets, it is necessary to overcome the limitations posed by coarse-resolution reanalysis datasets. This can be achieved by developing algorithms that consider the effects of surface properties on LSTs more precisely and by employing high-resolution satellite data like MODIS products combined with sophisticated reconstruction methods such as DINEOF and CDF matching.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do reconstructed LST datasets have for applications requiring high accuracy under varying atmospheric conditions?
Interpretation.Answer: Reconstructed LST datasets, which combine satellite observations with reanalysis data, provide high accuracy and continuity even under varying atmospheric conditions. These datasets are crucial for applications in meteorology, climate studies, hydrology, agriculture, and ecology, as they offer reliable temperature information across different land cover types, ensuring that data users can make informed decisions based on accurate temperature patterns.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenges in obtaining accurate Land Surface Temperature (LST) data from satellite remote sensing observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Remote sensing observations for Land Surface Temperature (LST) are inherently affected by cloud cover, leading to varying degrees of missing data in satellite-derived LST products. This cloud cover and other atmospheric conditions result in temporal and spatial discontinuities, limiting the application of LST products in related research areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to use a cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching-based method in reconstructing LST data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The CDF matching-based method is necessary because it corrects the ideal clear-sky LSTs to the real LSTs by integrating LSTs from the ERA5-Land climate reanalysis data, thereby addressing the limitations of reconstructing only missing LST values under ideal conditions and not under cloudy sky conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the high validation accuracy of the reconstructed LST dataset under various land cover types?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high validation accuracy is attributed to the use of the DINEOF method for reconstructing missing LST information, which shows good performance across all land cover types. It effectively combines the DINEOF reconstruction method with the CDF matching-based correction method, resulting in strong statistical metrics such as an average R of 0.971, minimal Bias, and low RMSE values.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using the cumulative distribution function matching method for correcting LST data from climate reanalysis datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of the cumulative distribution function matching method for correcting LST data from climate reanalysis datasets results in the reconstruction of real LSTs under all-sky conditions, effectively mitigating the impact of cloud cover on satellite-derived LST data.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to develop data collection methods that can reconstruct land surface temperature under both clear and cloudy sky conditions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Remote sensing observations for land surface temperature are significantly affected by cloud cover, leading to missing data. This limitation restricts the application of satellite-derived LST products, as many applications require continuous data. Developing methods to reconstruct LST under all weather conditions enhances the usability of these datasets across various research fields such as climate and hydrology.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind using a cumulative distribution function matching method to enhance land surface temperature datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of using a cumulative distribution function matching method is to correct the ideal clear-sky LSTs to real LSTs by integrating information from climate reanalysis data. This approach aims to mitigate the effects of cloud cover and atmospheric disturbances on LST estimations, thereby increasing the accuracy and applicability of the dataset for global studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why integrate satellite and reanalysis data in the creation of land surface temperature datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating satellite data with reanalysis data, such as ERA5-Land, allows for the creation of a continuous and high-resolution LST dataset. This integration leverages the spatial-temporal detail of satellite observations and the cloud influence information from reanalysis data, addressing the challenge of cloud-induced data gaps in satellite-derived LST products.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in reconstructing ideal clear-sky Land Surface Temperature (LST) from satellite data under cloud-contaminated conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involve first using the DINEOF reconstruction process to obtain the ideal clear-sky LSTs for cloud-contaminated areas. This is followed by correcting these ideal clear-sky LSTs to the real LSTs using a cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching-based method with LSTs from the ERA5-Land climate reanalysis data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers address the challenge of missing data due to cloud cover in satellite-derived LST products?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers can address this challenge by combining satellite-derived LST data, such as the MODIS LST products, with reanalysis data like the ERA5-Land's skin temperature data. The DINEOF method can be used to reconstruct missing LST information, and a cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching-based method can correct the ideal clear-sky LSTs to real LSTs.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodology is used to integrate Terra/Aqua MODIS LST products with ERA5-Land reanalysis data for creating a continuous global LST dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodology involves using Terra/Aqua MODIS LST products to reconstruct LST under ideal clear-sky conditions using an empirical orthogonal function interpolation method. Then, the reconstructed LST is integrated with ERA5-Land reanalysis data using a cumulative distribution function matching method to obtain LST under all-weather conditions, ultimately creating a continuous global LST dataset.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the reconstruction of land surface temperature data under cloudy conditions?
Enablement.Answer: The reconstruction of land surface temperature data under cloudy conditions is enabled through a combination of the DINEOF reconstruction method to obtain ideal clear-sky LSTs for cloud-contaminated areas, followed by a cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching-based method to correct these to real LSTs, utilizing ERA5-Land climate reanalysis data.

Enablement.Question: How do reanalysis datasets contribute to the enhancement of spatial and temporal continuity in land surface temperature observations?
Enablement.Answer: Reanalysis datasets contribute to the enhancement of spatial and temporal continuity in land surface temperature observations by providing comprehensive coverage that can be used to fill in gaps left by cloud cover in satellite data. The ERA5-Land reanalysis data are specifically used to complement satellite observations to create a globally continuous LST dataset.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in obtaining high-resolution LST data from reanalysis datasets, and how could these be overcome?
Expectation.Answer: Reanalysis datasets are generally output at coarse resolutions and do not fully account for surface properties affecting LSTs, limiting their application in cases requiring finer resolution. Overcoming these challenges may involve integrating high-resolution satellite data with reanalysis data using methods that adjust for cloud cover and atmospheric effects to produce more accurate LST reconstructions.

Expectation.Question: What might be the reasons for the difficulty in reconstructing real LSTs under cloudy conditions, and what methodologies are expected to improve this reconstruction?
Expectation.Answer: Reconstructing real LSTs under cloudy conditions is challenging because many algorithms only work under clear-sky conditions and require regional parameters from ground-based measurements, which are not effective when large areas of data are missing. To improve this, methods like DINEOF for initial reconstruction and CDF matching with reanalysis data for correction can enhance the accuracy and applicability of LST data under cloud cover.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the effectiveness of using a combination of DINEOF reconstruction and CDF matching-based correction methods for addressing cloud cover challenges in land surface temperature data collection?
Judgmental.Answer: The combination of DINEOF reconstruction and CDF matching-based correction methods is considered effective in addressing cloud cover challenges. The approach successfully reconstructs missing LST information across various land cover types, achieving high correlation and low bias, indicating it is a robust solution for handling cloud-contaminated areas in LST data collection.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how does the integration of MODIS and ERA5-Land data contribute to the reliability and continuity of land surface temperature datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of MODIS and ERA5-Land data enhances the reliability and continuity of land surface temperature datasets by leveraging the detailed spatial information from MODIS and the atmospheric information from ERA5-Land. This integration allows for the reconstruction of LST data under both clear and cloudy conditions, resulting in a high-quality, spatiotemporally continuous dataset that meets various research and application needs.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the potential benefits and limitations of using the 0.05° spatial resolution in reconstructing global land surface temperature datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: The 0.05° spatial resolution offers a fine granularity that is beneficial for detailed analysis and application across different land cover types globally. It facilitates high accuracy in temperature and emissivity data representation. However, the limitation may arise in computational demands and the need for extensive data processing capabilities, which could be challenging for large-scale, real-time applications.

Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing observations for land surface temperature (LST) are significantly affected by cloud cover, which leads to varying degrees of missing data in satellite-derived LST products. Clouds obstruct the thermal infrared signals used in remote sensing, causing interruptions in data collection and affecting the spatial and temporal continuity of LST products.

Assertion.Question: I am unsure about the methods used to reconstruct land surface temperature data under cloudy conditions.
Assertion.Answer: To reconstruct land surface temperature data under cloudy conditions, a method involving empirical orthogonal function interpolation is used to estimate ideal clear-sky LST. This is then combined with ERA5-Land climate reanalysis data using a cumulative distribution function matching method to correct and obtain real LST under all-weather conditions.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why reanalysis datasets are needed alongside satellite data to improve LST data quality.
Assertion.Answer: Reanalysis datasets, like ERA5-Land's skin temperature data, are used alongside satellite data to improve LST data quality because they provide additional information on atmospheric conditions that affect LST measurements. These datasets help mitigate the impact of cloud cover and other atmospheric disturbances on satellite observations, leading to more accurate and continuous LST data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the challenges of collecting land surface temperature data via remote sensing and how these challenges can be mitigated.
Request/Directive.Answer: Remote sensing observations for land surface temperature (LST) are significantly affected by cloud cover, leading to missing data in satellite-derived LST products. These challenges can be mitigated by using methods that reconstruct missing LST values under clear-sky conditions, such as the DINEOF reconstruction process, and by correcting these values under real conditions using cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching-based methods with reanalysis data, like ERA5-Land climate reanalysis data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the potential for expanding or refining datasets for global land surface temperature by incorporating additional data sources or methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: Expanding or refining datasets for global land surface temperature can involve incorporating additional data sources such as other satellite data products or higher-resolution climate reanalysis datasets. Additionally, refining the methods used, such as enhancing the accuracy of the DINEOF method or improving the CDF matching techniques, can further increase the dataset's quality. Exploring machine learning algorithms to predict missing values or using ground-based measurements to validate satellite data can also be beneficial for dataset enhancement.
